inputs.text: Inside a quiet Ming palace hall, soft lattice-window light falls on polished stone; a man sits centered, facing the camera, upper body visible above a wide redwood scholar’s 案台 (120 cm × 60 cm) whose front panel completely obscures his lower body; he wears a deep-black silk python robe with expansive sleeves spreading over the tabletop, white-jade belt snug at his waist, while the standard Ming dynasty 乌纱帽 (imperial court cap) rests on his head—its black fine-mesh gauze shaped front-low and back-high, forming a clean, slanted silhouette; at the rear crown, two long oval wing-like boards (帽翅) of the same dark gauze stretch left and right, each about 12 cm long, edges stitched with barely visible dark-gray thread; beneath the cap, a white silk net-band (网巾) wraps his gathered hair, knotting at the nape, every loop and knot catching soft side-light; the gauze’s minute hexagonal weave is crisply resolved, revealing faint intersections back-lit by natural window rays; on the table directly before him rests the existing blue-and-white porcelain vase—absolutely unchanged in pattern, color, or 20 cm diameter; his expression is mild and scholarly, hands relaxed at the table edge; palette of obsidian silk, antique gold trim, cool jade belt, sheer black gauze and crisp ceramic white, 50 mm lens, f/2.8, 8 K clarity, shallow depth, serene court ambiance.
